Multi-Layer Personalized Federated Learning for Mitigating Biases in Student Predictive Analytics

Yun-Wei Chu, Seyyedali Hosseinalipour, Elizabeth Tenorio, Laura Cruz,
Kerrie Douglas, Andrew S. Lan, Christopher G. Brinton Y. Chu, E. Tenorio, and C. Brinton are with the Elmore Family School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Purdue University, IN, USA. e-mail: {chu198, etenori, cgb}@purdue.edu S. Hosseinalipour is with the Department of Electrical Engineering, University at Buffalo (SUNY), NY, USA. email: alipour@buffalo.edu L. Cruz is with the Department of Engineering Education, University of Florida, FL, USA. e-mail: cruzcastrol@ufl.edu K. Douglas is with the School of Engineering Education, Purdue University, IN, USA. e-mail: douglask@purdue.edu A. Lan is with the Manning College of Information and Computer Sciences, University of Massachusetts Amherst, MA, USA. email: andrewlan@cs.umass.edu An abridged version [1] of this paper has been published in the 31st ACM International Conference on Information and Knowledge Management
Abstract

Traditional learning-based approaches to student modeling (e.g., predicting grades based on measured activities) generalize poorly to underrepresented/minority student groups due to biases in data availability. In this paper, we propose a Multi-Layer Personalized Federated Learning (MLPFL) methodology which optimizes inference accuracy over different layers of student grouping criteria, such as by course and by demographic subgroups within each course. In our approach, personalized models for individual student subgroups are derived from a global model, which is trained in a distributed fashion via meta-gradient updates that account for subgroup heterogeneity while preserving modeling commonalities that exist across the full dataset. To evaluate our methodology, we consider case studies of two popular downstream student modeling tasks, knowledge tracing and outcome prediction, which leverage multiple modalities of student behavior (e.g., visits to lecture videos and participation on forums) in model training. Experiments on three real-world datasets from online courses demonstrate that our approach obtains substantial improvements over existing student modeling baselines in terms of increasing the average and decreasing the variance of prediction quality across different student subgroups. Visual analysis of the resulting studentsâ€™ knowledge state embeddings confirm that our personalization methodology extracts activity patterns which cluster into different student subgroups, consistent with the performance enhancements we obtain over the baselines.

Index Terms:
federated learning, hierarchical learning, student modeling, personalization, de-biasing

1 Introduction

Oline learningÂ [2] has proven to be a critical component of todayâ€™s educational platforms, highlighted by its significant uptick in usage during the COVID-19 pandemicÂ [3]. The remote nature of online learning makes it harder for instructors to pay attention to each individual student and provide feedback at a personalized level. This has motivated the investigation of artificial intelligence (AI)-based approaches to delivering personalized instruction and feedback based on measured student progress in online learning activities [4, 5, 6].

Student modeling [7], and its associated research area, is an important research area since it provides information on the student factors that may be used to drive such efforts. There exist a wide range of student models, from those that analyze (i) student knowledge, such as item response theory [8] and models for knowledge tracing [9], to those that analyze (ii) student behavior within computer-based learning platforms, e.g., to detect psychological states [10, 11] and discover learning tendencies [12, 13, 14]. Since these student models are fitted from student data collected from real-world learning platforms, they are inherently prone to any biases that exist in the available data [15]. As a result, the research topic of de-biasing data-driven student models has gained recent traction; studies have investigated existing algorithmic biases in educational applications [16, 17] and explored how to impose constraints during model training to promote fairness across different student groups [18].

One common theme of these existing de-biasing works is that they study the bias/fairness aspects of a single global student model that is trained on all students dataÂ [19]. This setup is typically effective in AI applications since more data generally leads to improved model fit. However, this setup ignores the fact that underrepresented groups may not be well-captured by a population-level model, resulting in unfair and erroneous predictions that could be catastrophic for some students [20, 21, 22]. On the contrary, training separate local models for each student subgroup may not be effective since small subgroups do not have enough data for us to train an accurate model. In this work, we aim to develop a personalized student modeling methodology that addresses the data availability challenges across subgroups.

1.1 Federated Learning and Student Modeling

The recently proposed federated deep knowledge tracing (FDKT)Â [23] method is a first step towards coordinating between global and local student models, based on federated learning (FL)Â [24]. , a popular technique for enabling collaboration among models trained on heterogeneous local datasets through periodic global model aggregations. Beyond the conventional FedAvg algorithmÂ [25], research in Global FL has proposed various aggregation strategies to optimize the obtained global model, in terms of relevant objectives for different learning settings, e.g., Â [26, 27, 28, 29]. In particular, FedAttÂ [26] adds an attention layer to improve FL in terms of trained model accuracy, while FedAdagradÂ [27] and MOONÂ [28] aim to improve the speed of convergence. However, statistical heterogeneity across local data distributions â€“ i.e., non-i.i.d. (independent and identically distributed) data â€“ is an inherent characteristic of most FL applications that presents fundamental challenges to Global FLÂ [30]. This has motivated Personalized FL which aims to redefine the relationship between the local and global models for a better match to individual local datasetsÂ [31, 32]. In particular, Personalized FL shifts the optimization focus to individual local objectives, often by incorporating meta-functions into the definition of the global learning objectiveÂ [33, 34].

In student modeling, this statistical heterogeneity property manifests along several dimensions. FDKTÂ [23] addresses the heterogeneity arising from student training data being split across different schools. Applying the FL principle, local models are trained for each school, and updating between the global and local models is coordinated without transferring the data. While this setup is representative of some real-world educational settings, it ignores the bigger picture of heterogeneity across student subgroups such as race, gender, and other demographic variables. In particular, researchers in AI fairness have pointed to a pattern of underrepresented/minority groups with fewer data quantities tending to be ignored when training a general model, resulting in biases and ethical issuesÂ [35, 36].

The aggregation scheme in FDKT weights the local models according to â€œdata quality,â€ measured through fitting local psychometric models such as classical test theory and item response theory. This results in an implicit downweighting of underrepresented student subgroups due to a lack of data volume, which is not acceptable in our setting since the data from each group contains important information about how these students learn. We address this in our work by developing a Personalized FL methodology which accounts for heterogeneity across courses and demographics in a multi-tiered student modeling framework.

1.2 Activity-Based Student Modeling

Our student modeling approach will build upon and formalize two key observations from past educational data mining research that can further mitigate biases. These will come into play as we formalize two downstream student modeling applications for case-studies: knowledge tracing and outcome prediction.

The first observation is that patterns in student learning activity â€“ such as video-watching behavior, discussion forum interactions, and other clickstream logs (see FigureÂ 1(a)) â€“ contain signals of student performance in online coursesÂ [37, 38, 39, 40, 41, 42]. Since each student tends to generate a substantial number of activity measurements throughout a course, incorporating them may alleviate sparsity issues faced by prediction models trained on subgroups with fewer students.

The second observation is that distinctive patterns of learning activities can be identified both within and across student groups (e.g., different gender groups)Â [43, 44, 45]. This was originally discovered among in-person learning behaviors (e.g., participation and learning style), and more recently in digital environmentsÂ [46]. We thus aim to capture how sequences of learning activities (e.g., viewing a forum, then watching a specific video, then answering a specific quiz question) differ based on student subgroups in our construction of personalized FL models. However, online learning activities contain more noise than those capture in-person (e.g., a student accessing a video accidentally), making it difficult to identify these patterns through standard data mining techniquesÂ [37].

For example, considering one of the datasets in this paper, FigureÂ 1(b) depicts the heatmaps of differences observed when students engage in particular learning activities. Two cases are considered: (b1) between learners across a demographic group (all males vs. all females), and (b2) between learners within a subgroup (50% of the males vs. the other 50%, chosen randomly). Each heatmap value indicates the difference in the fraction of students engaged in the activity at that point in their learning trajectory. (b1) exhibits a more varied set of trajectories than (b2), consistent with the intuition that different subgroups have different learning behaviors, but (b2) still has noticeable differentials even though it is a comparison among a cross-section of the same subgroup. This further motivates our meta-learning approach to subgroup personalization, where any machine-identified commonalities in the data across the subgroups are captured in a global model that is further refinable based on local subgroup information. As we will see in Sec.Â 4.4, visualizations of the student embeddings learned by our methodology validate that distinctive activity patterns exist between subgroups.

1.3 Outline and Summary of Contributions

In this paper, we develop a federated student modeling methodology that personalizes prediction models for different data grouping criteria and mitigates the bias in data availability for underrepresented groups. Specifically, we make the following major contributions:

  • â€¢

    We design a Multi-Layer Personalized Federated Learning (MLPFL) methodology where local models associated with different student groupings are adapted from a global model (Section 2). This adaptation is in the form of meta-gradient updates taken on data that is localized to the specific course and/or student subgroup, instead of using data quality heuristics as in prior work, mitigating biases arising from heterogeneous data availability.

  • â€¢

    We consider two popular downstream student modeling tasks for our methodology, knowledge tracing and outcome prediction (Section 3.2). We formulate these based on multi-modal learning activity logs available in real-world online courses datasets (Section 3.1).

  • â€¢

    Through experiments on three online education datasets (Section 4), we demonstrate that our methodology significantly outperforms existing student modeling approaches in terms of improving prediction accuracy and reducing variance across subgroups (Section 4.1-4.3). We find this advantage appears at both the global and local model levels, resulting in a robust prediction framework that can adapt between different student groupings.

  • â€¢

    Our experiments further reveal that demographic-based MLPFL provides substantial improvements in student modeling compared to course-level personalization without demographic information. We also visually demonstrate that the student activity embeddings produced by our methodology are clustered based on subgroups (Section 4.4).

2 Multi-Layer Personalized Federated Learning

In this section, we introduce the training procedures of Multi-Layer Personalized Federated Learning (MLPFL) based on general modeling assumptions. We will detail the model structures for specific downstream educational tasks in Section 3.2.

The two layers we consider for our modeling hierarchy are courses and demographics. Since demographic information may not always be available, we consider two different scenarios, as depicted in Figure 2. The first scenario (Figure 2(a)) conducts personalized student modeling by course only. The second scenario (Figure 2 (b)) further considers personalization for each demographic subgroup within each course, i.e., when students have provided this information.

2.1 Scenario I: Personalized by Course

2.1.1 Data Partitioning for Personalization by Courses

2.1.2 Meta-Learning Personalization for Course-based Local Model

To facilitate personalization for different courses, our methodology obtains a separate local model for each course. The tasks handled locally are: (i) providing a course-personalized model for global aggregations and (ii) adapting the global model based on the local students in each course. Besides the local course models Î˜csubscriptÎ˜ğ‘\Theta_{c} we introduce in Section 2.1.1, we further define the global model as Î˜gsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘”\Theta_{{g}}. We aim to train a global model that is easily adaptable to each local course. To this end, we employ a meta-learning based personalized FL frameworkÂ [34] to seek the global model that solves the following optimization problem:

where Fcâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ¹ğ‘â‹…F_{c}(\cdot) is the meta-loss function of course cğ‘c, and fcâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘â‹…f_{c}(\cdot) is the original loss function, which is the sum of prediction loss (i.e., binary cross entropy loss from Section 3.2.1 and 3.2.2) over the dataset of course cğ‘c. The main difference between our loss function in (1) and the loss functions used in existing student modeling workÂ [47, 48] is that our loss function aims to minimize the loss of the adapted versions of the global model. This adaptation is based on one gradient descent step, i.e., term (a)ğ‘(a) in (1), which is taken over the local course cğ‘c dataset. That is, our method exploits the commonality of data across courses to train an adaptable global model, which can be easily tailored to each course.

To solve (1), we derive meta-gradient based local update steps. 2.1.3 Attention-Based Global Model Aggregation

The global modeling stage in our methodology handled two tasks: (i) aggregating the local models and (ii) synchronizing the course models with the resulting parameter vector for subsequent local model training rounds. Instead of using the standard averaging-based aggregation method from FedAvgÂ [25], we employ a recently developed attention-based aggregation method, FedAttÂ [26]. FedAtt introduces an attention mechanism for weighting local neural network models according to how far the parameters in each of their layers have deviated from the previous global model.

Formally, at each aggregation step, the global model receives two pieces of information: (i) all the local models Î˜c(k,E)subscriptsuperscriptÎ˜ğ‘˜ğ¸ğ‘\Theta^{(k,E)}_{c} (c=1,â‹¯,Cğ‘1â‹¯ğ¶c=1,\cdots,C), and (ii) the attention weight for each local model. The attention weight Î±c(k)subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘\alpha^{(k)}_{c} for local course model Î˜csubscriptÎ˜ğ‘\Theta_{c} is computed across its set of layers â„’â„’\mathcal{L} as follows::

Î±c(k)=âˆ‘â„“âˆˆâ„’softmaxâ€‹(â€–Î˜g(k)â€‹(â„“)âˆ’Î˜c(k,E)â€‹(â„“)â€–),subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘subscriptâ„“â„’softmaxnormsuperscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘”ğ‘˜â„“superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ¸â„“\alpha^{(k)}_{c}=\sum_{\ell\in\mathcal{L}}\textup{softmax}\left(\left\|\Theta_{{g}}^{(k)}({\ell})-\Theta_{c}^{(k,E)}(\ell)\right\|\right), (4)

where â„“âˆˆâ„’â„“â„’\ell\in\mathcal{L} denotes a particular neural network model layer, and Î˜g(k)â€‹(â„“)subscriptsuperscriptÎ˜ğ‘˜ğ‘”â„“\Theta^{(k)}_{g}(\ell) and Î˜c(k,E)â€‹(â„“)subscriptsuperscriptÎ˜ğ‘˜ğ¸ğ‘â„“\Theta^{(k,E)}_{c}(\ell) represent the parameter vector of the â„“â„“\ell-th layer in the global and local model, respectively, at the instance of global aggregation. The aggregated global model is then obtained as:

Î˜g(k+1)=Î˜g(k)âˆ’Ïµâ€‹âˆ‘câˆˆğ’Î±c(k)â€‹(Î˜g(k)âˆ’Î˜c(k,E)),superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘”ğ‘˜1superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘”ğ‘˜italic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘ğ’subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘”ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ¸\Theta_{{g}}^{(k+1)}=\Theta_{{g}}^{(k)}-\epsilon\sum_{c\in\mathcal{C}}\alpha^{(k)}_{c}\left(\Theta_{{g}}^{(k)}-\Theta_{c}^{(k,E)}\right), (5)

where Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is a tunable step-size. The full personalized FL procedure is summarized in AlgorithmÂ 1 and FigureÂ 2(a).

2.2 Scenario II: Personalized by Course and Demographics

2.2.1 Data Partitioning for Personalization by Demographic Variables

Open platforms, such as edX and Coursera, usually solicit studentsâ€™ demographic information when they register, which they can fill out voluntarily. Instead of considering personalization by courses, we further analyze detailed personalization by studentsâ€™ demographic in each course. Following the introduction of dataset partitioning, we further partition the dataset based on studentsâ€™ demographic information. In the following, we use the training set as an example to describe the partition criterion; the test set also follows the same rule when partitioning. We use Î©{c,I}ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ‘ğ¼ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡\Omega_{\{c,I\}}^{\mathsf{train}} to represent the students belonging to the training set who answered specific demographic information Iğ¼I within course cğ‘c. According to the open platform we consider, i.e., edX, we assume a binary choice of male and female for gender selection and group students into five continents according to their countries since no students claimed to be from Antarctica and countries in Oceania. Note that Î©{c,G}ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ‘ğºğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡\Omega_{\{c,G\}}^{\mathsf{train}} , Î©{c,C}ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ‘ğ¶ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡\Omega_{\{c,C\}}^{\mathsf{train}}, and Î©{c,Y}ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ‘ğ‘Œğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡\Omega_{\{c,Y\}}^{\mathsf{train}} are not necessarily the same since the demographic questions were asked independently and the students whichever demographic question that make them feel comfortable.

Î˜{c,Â¬I}subscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ¼\Theta_{\{c,\neg I\}} denotes the model built by Î©{c,Â¬I}ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ‘ğ¼ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡\Omega_{\{c,\neg I\}}^{\mathsf{train}}, and Î˜{c,I,x}subscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥\Theta_{\{c,I,x\}} represents the model constructed by the specific xğ‘¥x subgroup of demographic information Iğ¼I within course cğ‘c. When performing Multi-Layer Personalized Federated Learning in this section, we consider two settings: (i) training models by using Î˜{c,I,x}subscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥\Theta_{\{c,I,x\}} and (ii) training an additional model Î˜{c,Â¬I}subscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ¼\Theta_{\{c,\neg I\}} alongside Î˜{c,I,x}subscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥\Theta_{\{c,I,x\}} The prediction performance of each model then is tested on Î©{c,I,x}ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—\Omega_{\{c,I,x\}}^{\mathsf{test}} or Î©{c,Â¬I}ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ‘ğ¼ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—\Omega_{\{c,\neg I\}}^{\mathsf{test}} after the training procedure.

2.2.2 Meta-Learning Personalization for Demographic Local Models

In addition to construct separate course models, we build separate models for demographic subgroups to facilitate finer granular personalized predictions within each course. As shown in FigureÂ 2(b), we build separate subgroup-personalized models and increase the hierarchy during MLPFL training. Similar to the meta-learning local model personalization for courses in Sec.Â 2.1.2, the tasks handled locally are: (i) providing a subgroup-personalized model for global aggregations and (ii) adapting the global model based on the local subgroup dataset. Our aim is to train a global model that is easily adaptable to each local student subgroup. Therefore the optimization problem will change from (1) to:

minÎ˜â€‹âˆ‘câˆˆğ’âˆ‘xâˆˆğ’³F{c,I,x}â€‹(Î˜):=f{c,I,x}â€‹(Î˜âˆ’âˆ‡f{c,I,x}â€‹(Î˜)âŸ(b)),assignsubscriptÎ˜subscriptğ‘ğ’subscriptğ‘¥ğ’³subscriptğ¹ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥Î˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥subscriptâŸÎ˜âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥Î˜ğ‘\operatorname{\min}_{\Theta}\sum_{c\in\mathcal{C}}\sum_{x\in\mathcal{X}}F_{\{c,I,x\}}(\Theta):=f_{\{c,I,x\}}\big{(}\underbrace{\Theta-\nabla f_{\{c,I,x\}}(\Theta)}_{(b)}\big{)}, (6)

where F{c,I,x}â€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ¹ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥â‹…F_{\{c,I,x\}}(\cdot) is the meta-loss function of student subgroup xğ‘¥x (corresponding to information Iğ¼I) in course cğ‘c, and f{c,I,x}â€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥â‹…f_{\{c,I,x\}}(\cdot) is the original loss function, which is the sum of prediction loss over the dataset of group xğ‘¥x in course cğ‘c. The adaptation is based on one gradient descent step, i.e., term (b)ğ‘(b) in (6), which is taken over the local dataset of subgroup xğ‘¥x. That is, our method exploits the commonality of data across subgroups to train an adaptable global model, which can be easily tailored to each individual subgroup.

To solve (6), we derive meta-gradient based local update steps. Similar to Scenario I, the training also proceeds through a sequence of training rounds kâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,K}ğ‘˜1â‹¯ğ¾k\in\{1,\cdots,K\}, with each round consisting of multiple local training iterations eâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,E}ğ‘’1â‹¯ğ¸e\in\{1,\cdots,E\}. During each iteration eğ‘’e, the local subgroup-model Î˜{c,I,x}(e,k)superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥ğ‘’ğ‘˜\Theta_{\{c,I,x\}}^{(e,k)} is updated by meta-gradient:

Î˜{c,I,x}(k,e)=Î˜{c,I,x}(k,eâˆ’1)âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡F{c,I,x}â€‹(Î˜{c,I,x}(k,eâˆ’1)),e=1,â‹¯,E,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘’superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘’1ğœ‚âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘’1ğ‘’1â‹¯ğ¸\Theta_{\{c,I,x\}}^{(k,e)}=\Theta_{\{c,I,x\}}^{(k,e-1)}-\eta\nabla F_{\{c,I,x\}}\left(\Theta_{\{c,I,x\}}^{(k,e-1)}\right),~{}e=1,\cdots,E, (7)

where Î·ğœ‚\eta is the step size, and âˆ‡F{c,I,x}âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥\nabla F_{\{c,I,x\}} is the meta gradient.

2.2.3 Global Model Aggregation and Adaptation for Demographic Variables

We employ attention-based aggregation for global model construction. Since we have additional hierarchy for training, the global modeling stage in this scenario is responsible for four tasks: (i) aggregating local subgroup-models into course-models, (ii) aggregating course-models into global model, (iii) synchronizing course-models with resulting global parameters for course-level adaptation, and (iv) synchronizing subgroup-models with course-level parameters for subgroup-level adaptation.

Formally, at each aggregation step, local subgroup-models are first aggregated into several course-models for each course as:

Î˜c(k+1)=Î˜c(k)âˆ’Ïµâ€‹âˆ‘xâˆˆğ’³Î±{c,I,x}(k)â€‹(Î˜c(k)âˆ’Î˜{c,I,x}(k,E))â€‹âˆ€I,superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ‘˜1superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ‘˜italic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘¥ğ’³subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ¸for-allğ¼\Theta_{{c}}^{(k+1)}=\Theta_{c}^{(k)}-\epsilon\sum_{x\in\mathcal{X}}\alpha^{(k)}_{\{c,I,x\}}\left(\Theta_{c}^{(k)}-\Theta_{\{c,I,x\}}^{(k,E)}\right)\forall I, (8)

where Î±{c,I,x}(k)subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥\alpha^{(k)}_{\{c,I,x\}} is the layer-wisely computed attention weight for local subgroup-models:

Î±{c,I,x}(k)=âˆ‘â„“âˆˆâ„’softmaxâ€‹(â€–Î˜c(k)â€‹(â„“)âˆ’Î˜{c,I,x}(k,E)â€‹(â„“)â€–),subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥subscriptâ„“â„’softmaxnormsuperscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ‘˜â„“superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ¸â„“\alpha^{(k)}_{\{c,I,x\}}=\sum_{\ell\in\mathcal{L}}\textup{softmax}\left(\left\|\Theta_{{c}}^{(k)}({\ell})-\Theta_{\{c,I,x\}}^{(k,E)}(\ell)\right\|\right), (9)

with â„’â„’\mathcal{L} denoting the set of layers. After aggregating the subgroup-models into course-models, the global model Î˜gsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘”\Theta_{g} receive the parameters of each course-model Î˜csubscriptÎ˜ğ‘\Theta_{c} and performs attention-based aggregation as follows:

Î˜ğ—€(k+1)=Î˜ğ—€(k)âˆ’Ïµâ€‹âˆ‘câˆˆğ’Î±c(k)â€‹(Î˜ğ—€(k)âˆ’Î˜c(k+1)),superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ—€ğ‘˜1superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ—€ğ‘˜italic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘ğ’subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ—€ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ‘˜1\Theta_{\mathsf{g}}^{(k+1)}=\Theta_{\mathsf{g}}^{(k)}-\epsilon\sum_{c\in\mathcal{C}}\alpha^{(k)}_{c}\left(\Theta_{\mathsf{g}}^{(k)}-\Theta_{c}^{(k+1)}\right), (10)

where Î±c(k)subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘\alpha^{(k)}_{c} is the attention weight for course-models:

Î±c(k)=âˆ‘â„“âˆˆâ„’softmaxâ€‹(â€–Î˜ğ—€(k)â€‹(â„“)âˆ’Î˜c(k+1)â€‹(â„“)â€–),subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘subscriptâ„“â„’softmaxnormsuperscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ—€ğ‘˜â„“superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ‘˜1â„“\alpha^{(k)}_{c}=\sum_{\ell\in\mathcal{L}}\textup{softmax}\left(\left\|\Theta_{\mathsf{g}}^{(k)}({\ell})-\Theta_{c}^{(k+1)}(\ell)\right\|\right), (11)

where â„“âˆˆâ„’â„“â„’\ell\in\mathcal{L} denotes a particular model layer. The full MLPFL algorithm is summarized in AlgorithmÂ 2 and FigureÂ 2(b). Note that, in Scenario II, there are two steps of synchronization after Î˜ğ—€(k+1)superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ—€ğ‘˜1\Theta_{\mathsf{g}}^{(k+1)} has been aggregated compared with Scenario I. The first synchronization is adapting global model Î˜gsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘”\Theta_{g} as a temporary course-model Î˜câ€²superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘â€²\Theta_{c}^{\prime} as shown in line 6 of AlgorithmÂ 2. This course adaptation is done by one step update by using a batch of student within course cğ‘c. We use stratified sampling to select a few students within each subgroup to form this batch without bias. After the course adaptation, the second step is to synchronize and adapt subgroup-models with course-models. Specifically, in each round kğ‘˜k, the local subgroup model is initialized as Î˜c(k,0)=Î˜c(k)â€²superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ‘˜0superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘superscriptğ‘˜â€²\Theta_{c}^{(k,0)}=\Theta_{{c}}^{(k)^{\prime}}, where Î˜c(k)â€²superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘superscriptğ‘˜â€²\Theta_{{c}}^{(k)^{\prime}} is the temporary course-model adapted from global model.

3 Datasets and Prediction Tasks

In this section, we describe the datasets we consider and formalize the downstream student modeling prediction tasks we employ to evaluate our methodology.

3.1 Datasets

We collect our datasets from Purdue Universityâ€™s online courses on the edX platform (\urlwww.edx.org). We study three graduate-level online courses: Fiber Optic Communications (FOC), Quantum Detectors and Sensors (QDS), and Essentials of MOSFETs (MOSFETs). Each course consists of a series of lecture videos, some of which have an end-of-video quiz that assesses student learning progress. Moreover, each course provides a discussion forum page for students to discuss with each other. The platform also records each studentâ€™s final grade, which is a pass or fail label based on the grading policy. Summary statistics of the three courses are given in TableÂ I, emphasizing a broad range of activity levels for our evaluation. The pass rate distributions for each student subgroup are also summarized in TableÂ II.

Each time a student uğ‘¢u accesses a lecture video vcsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘v_{c} of course cğ‘c, their activity is recorded with the following information: student ID, course ID, video ID, and UNIX timestamp. The in-video quizzes for each of the courses consist of a single multiple-choice question or a True/False question, appearing at the end of the video. When student uğ‘¢u submits an answer to the in-video question for video vcsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘v_{c}, the platform records the studentâ€™s response ru,vcâˆˆ{0,1}subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¢subscriptğ‘£ğ‘01r_{u,v_{c}}\in\{0,1\}. ru,vc=0subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¢subscriptğ‘£ğ‘0r_{u,v_{c}}=0 indicates an incorrect response of student uğ‘¢u on video vcsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘v_{c} quiz; and ru,vc=1subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¢subscriptğ‘£ğ‘1r_{u,v_{c}}=1 otherwise.

Discussion forums are considered an extension of traditional learning that promote dialogue, reflection, and knowledge constructionÂ [40]. They are particularly important in virtual learning environments, motivating us to consider them for student knowledge modeling. The learning platform records forum-participation activities fuâˆˆ{forum_post,forum_reply,forum_view}subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¢forum_postforum_replyforum_viewf_{u}\in\{\textsf{forum\_post},\textsf{forum\_reply},\textsf{forum\_view}\} when student uğ‘¢u visits the discussion forum page. forum_post indicates a student either started a new thread or made a post in a thread, forum_reply represents a student replied to another studentâ€™s post, and forum_view indicates a student visited a thread without posting or replying.

3.2 Student Prediction Modeling Tasks

In order to evaluate our proposed training procedure MLPFL, we implement two downstream tasks, knowledge tracingÂ [47] and student outcome predictionÂ [1].

4 Experimental Evaluation

We now conduct experiments on our three online course datasets from SectionÂ 3.1 to evaluate our personalization methodology MLPFL.

4.1 Model Baselines

We compare the performance of MLPFL against baselines in several different configurations. These configurations differ in terms of several attributes: (i) scenario (i.e., scenario I and II we introduced in SectionÂ 2.1 andÂ 2.2), (ii) architecture (i.e., local (L), global (G), and personalized (P) model), (iii) FL aggregation method (i.e., average-based aggregation (AV), attention-based aggregation (AT)), and (iv) hierarchy information (for the scenario with demographic personalization). For conciseness, we will use a general structure [<<Scenario>>-<<Architecture>>-<<Aggregation>>-<<Hierarchy>>] to represent each baseline according to the attributes listed in TableÂ III. <<Hierarchy>> appears for scenario II to indicate which level of the hierarchy â€“ bottom (B), middle (M), top (T) â€“ is used for the final adapted model. For example, [sc1-G-AV] represents the global model with average-based aggregation in scenario I, and [sc2-P-AT-B] corresponds to the personalized model that adapts the attention-aggregated global model based on the data of the bottom level (demographic subgroups) in scenario II.

4.1.1 Algorithms for scenario I (<<Scenario>> = sc1)

Local Modeling (<<Architecture>> = L) We construct a local baseline [sc1-L] by building several local models based on student data in each course. More specifically, we train three local models, one for each course câˆˆğ’ğ‘ğ’c\in\mathcal{C}, using datasets Î©cğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡subscriptsuperscriptÎ©ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡ğ‘\Omega^{\mathsf{train}}_{c} and evaluate each model on Î©cğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—subscriptsuperscriptÎ©ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—ğ‘\Omega^{\mathsf{test}}_{c}.

Global Modeling (<<Architecture>> = G) We implement three global models for scenario I. One of them, [sc1-G], is a centralized model without FL, while the others, [sc1-G-AV] & [sc1-G-AT], are Global FL models.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet [sc1-G]: A centralized global model is trained on all the studentsâ€™ training data Î©ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡superscriptÎ©ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡\Omega^{\mathsf{train}} collected from all the courses and evaluated on Î©ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—superscriptÎ©ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—\Omega^{\mathsf{test}}.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet [sc1-G-AV]: A federated global model is implemented from FedAvgÂ [25]. We first train several local models Î˜c(k,e)superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘’\Theta_{c}^{(k,e)} on Î©cğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡subscriptsuperscriptÎ©ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡ğ‘\Omega^{\mathsf{train}}_{c}, without meta-learning, for training round kğ‘˜k. After Eğ¸E iterations, FedAvg weighs each local model based on the number of students in each course to conduct a standard global aggregation:

Î˜ğ—€(k+1)=âˆ‘câˆˆğ’NcNâ€‹Î˜c(k,E),superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ—€ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘ğ’subscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptÎ˜ğ‘˜ğ¸ğ‘\Theta_{\mathsf{g}}^{(k+1)}=\sum_{c\in\mathcal{C}}\frac{N_{c}}{N}\Theta^{(k,E)}_{c}, (20)

where Ncsubscriptğ‘ğ‘N_{c} is the number of students within course cğ‘c, and N=âˆ‘câˆˆğ’Ncğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ’subscriptğ‘ğ‘N=\sum_{c\in\mathcal{C}}N_{c}. After Kğ¾K global aggregations, we take Î˜ğ—€(K)superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ—€ğ¾\Theta_{\mathsf{g}}^{(K)} as [sc1-G-AV] to evaluate FedAvg on Î©cğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ‘ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—\Omega_{c}^{\mathsf{test}}.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet [sc1-G-AT]: An attention-based federated global algorithm is implemented from FedAttnÂ [26]. After Eğ¸E local iterations, FedAttn aggregates local models based on the attention mechanism with the weights introduced in (4). After Kğ¾K global aggregations, the aggregated global model Î˜ğ—€(K)superscriptsubscriptÎ˜ğ—€ğ¾\Theta_{\mathsf{g}}^{(K)} defined in (5) is evaluated on Î©cğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ‘ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—\Omega_{c}^{\mathsf{test}}.

Personalized Modeling (<<Architecture>> = P) We consider two versions of our local model personalization in FL for scenario I: [sc1-P-AV] and [sc1-P-AT]. Both of these personalized models adapt the global model based on meta-updates from the data in each course.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet [sc1-P-AV]: This follows the algorithm we introduced in SectionÂ 2.1, while replacing our attention-based aggregation method in (4) and (5) with the averaging-based aggregation of PerFedÂ [34].

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet [sc1-P-AT]: This is the full version of our course-based personalized method from SectionÂ 2.1.

4.1.2 Algorithms for scenario II (<<Scenario>> = sc2)

Local Modeling (<<Architecture>> = L) In scenario II, the bottom hierarchy is grouped by demographic variables. Therefore, we build a local baseline [sc2-L] with a separate model for each of these demographic subgroups. Each model in [sc2-L] is trained on student data Î©{c,I,x}ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡subscriptsuperscriptÎ©ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥\Omega^{\mathsf{train}}_{\{c,I,x\}} for a specific subgroup {c,I,x}ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥\{c,I,x\} (i.e., subgroup xğ‘¥x of demographic variable Iğ¼I in course cğ‘c) and evaluated on Î©{c,I,x}ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—subscriptsuperscriptÎ©ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥\Omega^{\mathsf{test}}_{\{c,I,x\}}.

Global Modeling (<<Architecture>> = G) We also consider a centralized global [sc2-G] and several federated global models [sc2-G-AV-M] & [sc2-G-AT-M] & [sc2-G-AV-T] & [sc2-G-AT-T]. For the federated global models, we first train several local models based on the demographic subgroups within each course. Then, we aggregate them to form different global models at each level (i.e., course(middle)-level global models ([sc2-G-AV-M] & [sc2-G-AT-M]) and top level global models ([sc2-G-AV-T] & [sc2-G-AT-T])).

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet [sc2-G]: Architecturally, this is the same as [sc1-G] because they both use all students Î©ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡superscriptÎ©ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡\Omega^{\mathsf{train}} to build one model. However, we evaluate [sc2-G] on each demographic subgroup Î©{c,I,x}ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—subscriptsuperscriptÎ©ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘¥\Omega^{\mathsf{test}}_{\{c,I,x\}} instead of each course.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet [sc2-G-AT-T]: This applies the attention aggregation mechanism to [sc2-G-AT-M] and obtains the top-level global model based on (10).

Personalized Modeling (<<Architecture>> = P) We consider five personalized algorithms in this scenario. One of the baselines, FedIRT, uses educational theory for the aggregation, while four â€“[sc2-P-AV-M], [sc2-P-AT-M], [sc2-P-AT-B], and [sc2-P-AT-B]â€“ are different configurations of our MLPFL algorithm. [sc2-P-AV-M] and [sc2-P-AT-M] are the course(middle)-level personalizations adapted from the top global model, while [sc2-P-AV-B] and [sc2-P-AT-B] are the corresponding demographic(bottom)-level personalizations adapted from the course(middle)-level models.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet FedIRT: This is based on the federated deep knowledge tracing (FDKT)Â [23] method discussed in SectionÂ 1. FDKT employs classical test theory and item response theory (IRT)Â [50] to calculate the score representing the â€œdata qualityâ€ of local subgroups, and uses the scores to weight each subgroup when aggregating models. For our setting, we implement the model update and aggregation method by calculating the IRT confidence Î±xğ–¨ğ–±ğ–³subscriptsuperscriptğ›¼ğ–¨ğ–±ğ–³ğ‘¥\alpha^{\mathsf{IRT}}_{x} for each student subgroup xğ‘¥x in scenario II, based on the studentsâ€™ answers to the end-of-video quizzes. Within each course, local models are trained for each demographic variable. Following Â [23], local model updates are based on interpolation, where the initial model for training round kğ‘˜k is defined as:

where

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet [sc2-P-AV-M]: This is built by taking one meta-update from [sc2-G-AV-T], i.e., followingÂ (7). This creates one personalized model for each course, using stratified sampling of students in each subgroup for each course.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet [sc2-P-AT-M]: This baseline is adapted from [sc2-G-AT-T] by taking one meta-update, as in [sc2-P-AV-M].

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet [sc2-P-AV-B]: This is constructed through one further meta-update step from the course-level models in [sc2-P-AV-M]. It uses the datasets from each demographic subgroup to create a separate model for each subgroup in each course.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet [sc2-P-AT-B]: Taking one further meta-update step from [sc2-P-AT-M], [sc2-P-AT-B] corresponds to the full MLPFL method we introduced in Section 2.2.2- 2.2.3.

4.2 Implementation and Evaluation Metric

We perform 5-fold cross-validation on each dataset and randomly select 20% of the students in the training set for validation. For all neural network architecturesâ€“ LSTM in Knowledge Tracing and GRU in Outcome Predictionâ€“ the hidden state dimension is 48. 50 training epochs are used for non-FL approaches ([sc1-L], [sc1-G], [sc2-L], and [sc2-G]), and for FL methods, the global aggregations (Kğ¾K) and local iterations (Eğ¸E) are set to be 10 and 5, respectively. For all models, the hyper-parameters are determined by a grid search over the search space given in TableÂ IV. We test all combinations of parameters for each model and use the one achieving the highest accuracy in Section Â 4.3.

To evaluate the prediction performance for both downstream tasks, we use the standard Area Under the ROC Curve (AUC) metric. Random guessing will result in an AUC of 0.5, while a perfect model has an AUC of 1. We execute each experiment five times with random initialization for each method and report the average and standard deviation of AUC. We evaluate on the test set using the model at the training epoch with the highest validation AUC value. In scenario I, we measure the AUC of the adapted course models obtained after performing one local epoch on the global model for each course. For scenario II, we measure the AUC after two steps of adaptation: (i) performing one meta-update on the global to form course models, and (ii) performing one local epoch on the course model for each student subgroup.

4.3 Experimental Results

In TablesÂ V and VI, we compare our method to the baselines in terms of the predictive quality of knowledge tracing and outcome prediction achieved on each course in scenario I. For scenario II, Table Â VII, Â IX, and Â XI compare the performance of knowledge tracing on each student group for our method and the baselines, while TableÂ VIII, Â X, and Â XII are the results for outcome prediction. Finally, FigureÂ 3 compares the distribution of AUCs obtained by FedIRT and MLPFL across all courses and demographic subgroups.

In this section, all results are shown on the set of students who provided specific demographic information Iğ¼I; we train models on Î©c,Iğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ‘ğ¼ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡\Omega_{c,I}^{\mathsf{train}} and test them on each subgroup of Î©c,Iğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ‘ğ¼ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—\Omega_{c,I}^{\mathsf{test}}. Specifically, we divide the dataset into groups by gender, continent, and age information for the experiments in TablesÂ VII&VIII, IX&X, andÂ XI&XII, respectively. We defer the results on incorporating students who did not disclose their personal information (i.e., the models trained on {Î©c,Iğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡,Î©Â¬Iğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡}superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ‘ğ¼ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ¼ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡\{\Omega_{c,I}^{\mathsf{train}},\Omega_{\neg I}^{\mathsf{train}}\} and tested on each subgroup of {Î©c,Iğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—,Î©Â¬Iğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—}superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ‘ğ¼ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ¼ğ—ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—\{\Omega_{c,I}^{\mathsf{test}},\Omega_{\neg I}^{\mathsf{test}}\}) to SectionÂ A of the Appendix; the results are qualitatively similar.

4.3.1 Discussion for scenario I

From TablesÂ V and VI, we see that in many cases, there is not a large difference in performance between the locally trained [sc1-L] for each course and the centrally trained [sc1-G] across courses. This is a key motivation for personalization: despite [sc1-G] containing significantly larger training data, it is not preserving course-specific information. On the other hand, [sc1-G] outperforms both versions of global FL ([sc1-G-AV] and [sc1-G-AT]) in most cases, suggesting that centralized training across the full dataset is at least more useful than decentralized models when personalization is not employed.

Across TablesÂ V andÂ VI, we see that our proposed personalized models ([sc1-P-AV] and [sc1-P-AT]) obtain anywhere from 15-25% improvement in AUC over the non-personalized models, depending on the course, aggregation, and downstream task. The improvements obtained by the personalized models show the significance of adapting the global models based on local students within each course. Compared to [sc1-P-AV], MLPFL ([sc1-P-AT]) performs better on most courses, confirming our intuition on the advantages of layer-wise model aggregations with an attention mechanism. Importantly, these findings suggest that even without demographic information, our MLPFL methodology is able to obtain substantial improvement in student modeling through course-level personalizations.

4.3.2 Discussion for scenario II

In TablesÂ VII, IX, and XI, for knowledge tracing, we observe that the local model [sc2-L] provides on average 54% AUC on each subgroup according to different demographic groupings , and in TablesÂ VIII,Â X, and Â XII, we find on average 60% AUC for outcome prediction. While providing moderate improvements over [sc1-L], these results confirm our hypothesis that small subgroups do not have enough data to train high accuracy models individually.. On the other hand, unlike in scenario I, we see that the centralized global model [sc2-G] does not necessarily outperform the global federated models ([sc2-G-AV-M]&[sc2-G-AT-M] and [sc2-G-AV-T]&[sc2-G-AT-T]). This is particularly true for underrepresented subgroups. For example, in TableÂ VIII, for the MOSFETs dataset, [sc2-G] obtains the highest performance for the male subgroup among the non-personalized models, while two of the global FL models noticeably outperform it on the female subgroup. As another example, in Table 10, for the QDS dataset, [sc2-G-AT-M] outperforms [sc2-G] noticeably for all subgroups except North America. By systematically incorporating such subgroup heterogeneity, the personalized models are able to obtain substantial improvements across datasets and subgroups, as we discuss further next.

For both the knowledge tracing task (TablesÂ VII,Â IX, andÂ XI) and the outcome prediction task (TablesÂ VIII,Â X, andÂ XII), we see that our ML-PFL methodology obtains substantial improvements over the non-personalized models on each demographic subgroup. Specifically, for the FOC and QDS datasets, we obtain 15-35% improvement in AUC over the highest performing non-personalized model across subgroups. The improvements obtained by the personalized models are noticeable but more limited in the MOSFETs dataset, possibly due to its overall smaller size (see TableÂ I). For both downstream tasks, MLPFL consistently outperforms FedIRT except in 4 of the Â 50 subgroup cases across courses, confirming the benefits offered by our meta learning-based personalization approach. This improvement validates our hypothesis that weighting student subgroups based on their â€œdata qualityâ€ as in FedIRT may lose important information on subgroup heterogeneity, which is captured by our redefinition of the global model inÂ (6). Moreover, FedIRT does not consider course-specific modeling, whereas our personalized architecture adapts the student models across different courses and demographics.

These results also show how our methodology benefits from the personalization hierarchy. Specifically, in conducting the meta-updates that move from [sc2-G-AV-T] to [sc2-P-AV-M] and [sc2-G-AT-T] to [sc2-P-AT-M], we find that the course-level personalized models outperform the global models by at least 15% AUC for both downstream tasks. By considering the lowest-layer subgroupings and performing additional meta-updates that move from [sc2-P-AV-M] to [sc2-P-AV-B] and [sc2-P-AT-M] to [sc2-P-AT-B], we see that demographic-level personalized models further improve the AUC by 7%-9% on the FOC and QDS datasets over course-level personalized models. Bulding upon our MLPFL results for scenario I, this shows how our personalization methodology benefits from increasing amounts of information available about students, whereas the non-personalized FL models do not show this trend when moving from top to middle layer modeling.

Finally, FigureÂ 3 compares both the mean and variance in prediction quality obtained across all courses by FedIRT and our bottom-layer MLPFL personalization algorithms when modeling for each demographic subgroup. We can see that MLPFL consistently provides an improvement in mean AUC over FedIRT, with the attention mechanism providing an extra boost. Importantly, we also see that [sc2-P-AT-B] reduces the AUC variance across subgroups in five of the six cases. The exception case is the one with the lowest variance across all methods. The increase in mean and reduction in variance of prediction quality provided by MLPFL confirms that it lessens the impact of data subgroup availability biases in student modeling.

4.4 Embedding Visualization

We employ t-SNE to visualize the learned studentsâ€™ activity representations in a 2D space to qualitatively assess the intepretability of our methodology. In FigureÂ 4, we plot the student embeddings for knowledge tracing according to different courses in scenario I, while FigureÂ 5 shows the embeddings based on the gender demographic grouping in scenario II. We defer the visualizations for other demographic subgroups in scenario II to AppendixÂ B; the results are qualitatively similar. All models are trained on Î©ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡superscriptÎ©ğ—ğ—‹ğ–ºğ—‚ğ—‡\Omega^{\mathsf{train}}, and the student embeddings are the combined hidden state h~usubscript~hğ‘¢\widetilde{\textbf{h}}_{u} (Section Â 3.2.2) after the attention module that is used to predict their learning outcomes. The colors of the dots represent the corresponding student groups.

In FigureÂ 4(a), we can see that the centralized global model does not generate embeddings that differentiate students in different courses for scenario I. In FigureÂ 4(b), unsurprisingly, we see that local modeling produces embeddings which cluster by course with linear separation between the clusters, since each course model is learned independently. Compared to these, the embeddings learned by federated learning (FigureÂ 4(c)&(d)) also demonstrate clustering patterns according to different courses. In FigureÂ 4(d), we can see that the distribution learned by MLPFL is more separated by course due to the meta-update personalization applied to the model in FigureÂ 4(c). This clustering pattern is correlated with our methodâ€™s better inference ability in downstream task prediction: it preserves local attributes pertaining to each course while leveraging global commonalities in student modeling that are present across courses.

For scenario II, in FigureÂ 5, we can see that the student embeddings learned by MLPFL are also well-organized, reflecting specific course and gender demographic subgroups. It is hard to differentiate different courses and subgroups from the centralized global model (FigureÂ 5(a)). Starting with the federated global model (FigureÂ 5(b)), a more clustered distribution emerges as personalization steps are taken to the middle and bottom of the hierarchy in FigureÂ 5(c) andÂ 5(d). Compared to the course-level personalized model in FigureÂ 5(c), the distribution learned by MLPFL personalized by demographic information in FigureÂ 5(d) has denser clusters due to the additional meta-updates. The same clustering pattern when personalizing according to different continent and age information can be seen from FigureÂ 7 in SectionÂ A of the Appendix. These visualizations confirm the ability of MLPFL to adapt a global model to each student subgroup, helping us learn more expressive and predictive representations of student behavior, since we exploit available information unique to each subgroup that would be otherwise discarded.

These visuals show that student embeddings are at least moderately correlated with the specific student subgroup. For instance, in case of gender (FigureÂ 5(c)), males in course 3 tend to appear on the left side of the figure, females in course 2 tend to be at the top, and females in course 1 are on the upper right of the figure. The same phenomenon can be observed in other subplots of FigureÂ 7(a3)&(b3). These results suggest that students from different subgroups exhibit some unique learning behaviors, which our meta learning-based personalization approach takes into account via tailoring global models according to these groups.

5 Conclusion

In this paper, we developed a Multi-Layer Personalized Federated Learning (MLPFL) framework for mitigating biases in student modeling stemming from data availability. Our approach is based on meta learning, where local models corresponding to different student subgroups are adapted from a shared global model crafted to incorporate the personalization step. We applied our framework to two student modeling tasks: (i) knowledge tracing and (ii) outcome prediction, modeling student activities when they interact with an online learning platform. Our proposed method considers personalization in a hierarchical manner: first by course (if there are multiple courses), and then by student demographic subgroup within each course (if this information is provided to the model). Evaluation on three online course datasets showed that our methodology outperforms baseline algorithms in terms of improving prediction quality for every course and student subgroup considered. Moreover, well-organized student embeddings learned by our method were seen to be correlated with improved student modeling.
